text: - Good afternoon.
Thank you both for joining the AWS Studio.
- [Both] Good afternoon.
- Let's jump right in with a few intros

starting with you Nahum,
and then over to you Zeb.
- I'm Nahum.

I work in Swisscom as a
senior DevOps engineer
and I'm researching the 5G core
in the public cloud in AWS.
- I'm Zeb Khan.
I work in EC2 product management team.

So in that team we work with
customers who have workloads

that cannot be completely
run in the region
so they need to be run in local zone

and outposts for latency or
data sovereignty purposes.

And my focus is particularly
on telco workloads
specifically packet core and IMS.
- Let's unpack why we're here today.
We're here to talk about building
cloud native mobile cores on AWS.
So let's start with you Nahum,
as you think about the design principles

for building that cloud
native mobile core,
what comes to mind?
What are you thinking about
and what were your customers telling you?

- Actually, the important
thing is to shift the focus
from monolithic architecture
to microservice-based architecture.
So doing this and shifting the focus

on microservices architecture
allows us to be more flexible

and having the different
tools, different workloads run
in many different ways,
and in this case and on containers.
- And so from your perspective, Zeb,

this is something you
focus on all day long.

How is this emblematic
of your overall strategy
of empowering telco operators
to build these cloud native solutions?
- No, yeah.
So I mean, customers like Swisscom

and feedback that we also get
from other customers is that
they want to shift their focus
from managing network functions
to managing customer experiences.

So from that perspective, it's
very important for customers
to improve their time to market,

improve the overall aspect
related to the maintenance
of their 5G Core.

So activities such as
upgrades and updates that,
in prior generation, used to take
a significant amount of efforts.
So including human resources

and these efforts used to
be very CapEx intensive.

So that sort of limit
the level of innovation

and the pace at which our
CSPs could iteratively

build new experiences and
launch those experiences
without dedicating CapEx and resources.
So they want to get away from that model.

And microservices is
sort of like the vehicle
for using that model so that they can have

much fine granular
control of the life cycle
of the network function.

They can eliminate
undifferentiated heavy lifting
related to running these workloads.

So for example, I mean,
if there are aspects

such as managing control
plan of Kubernetes
or if there are aspects related to getting
storage as a managed service.
If those aspects can be managed by AWS,
then our customers can focus on
creating new services.

And just a couple of
more things I remember,

feedback I received from
customers is also that,
they want an architecture that is portable
across AWS cloud continuum.

So for them, it doesn't
matter that which location

and for which use case they're
deploying the use case.
They want an architecture that allow them

to select any arbitrary
location based on the use case.

So if it's one of AWS 31
regions or 32 local zones,

or even outpost on-prem,
they want the architecture

to be consistent and same
across the cloud continuum
so that they don't have to manage

different infrastructure
stacks for different use cases.
- So it's not just location agnostic,
it's topology agnostic though,
what customers we're asking for

across this range of
cloud continuum solutions.
That's great. That's great.

Maybe let's talk a little
bit about the strategy
from an operational perspective.
How do we work with our customers,

the likes of Swisscom, to
help develop these solutions?
What does that process look like?
The collaboration, engineer to engineer,
take us behind the scenes.
- Sure.
So there are a couple of key aspects.
One is that 5G core is,

or in general packet core
is very complex workload

which is basically
provided by different ISVs
and different customers have,

and even for different network
functions within packet core,

choose to go with different
ISVs for various reasons.

Now, so one of the most
important things that we do

as collaboration with
customers like Swisscom
is that we collaborate with their key ISVs
and we help their ISVs to actually adopt
the cloud native design principles
so that in turn they can offload
a lot of undifferentiated heavy lifting
that they have to do so that their stack
and their network functions are portable
and can be deployed and managed at scale
with rapid innovation.
So one example I can give you is like,
previously if ISVs used to design
their own front-end load balancers,

or if they had their own
solution for replicating data

for high availability, they
don't have to anymore with,

like let's say AWS auto-scaling,
AWS-managed load balancers.

In EBS we have utilities
where you can create

like volume snapshots and put
them across different regions.
You can have lifecycle policies for S3

to manage where you
want to keep your data.
So with all of these capabilities provided

as managed service, even our
ISVs in packet core ecosystem
can focus more on providing the features
that matters to customer like Swisscom

so that they can launch
new products and services.
- Indeed.

We'll switch to the
microservice architecture
on having smaller building blocks,

what we aim as well is
to have more frequent
deployments in the network.
So basically, as Zeb said before,
if we envision constant improvement,
constant deployment of the new features,

we can be faster to give our
customers what they want,

that is new features and
have readily available

in our network services
that they can use and enjoy.
And at the end, it's all about that,

about creating value for
our customers, focusing,
shifting the focus from building NFs

from building nodes on,
to building services.
- So let's start talking a little bit more
about the deployment.

What exactly did you build
and how was it architected
in a cloud native way?
And maybe even on top of that,
were there particular features of AWS

that were particularly
attractive in selecting the cloud
as the right deployment method for this?
- Yes, indeed.

What we focused on a first
place, it was automation.
So we are building the whole 5G Core,
not aiming to have working features
or being, having the latest thing deployed
but having a structure, an architecture,
and something that can be
entirely automated from end-to-end.
So from that point of view,
we have been using different AWS services.
The Code Suite for example.
So we use CodeBuilder and CodePipeline
to automate end-to-end.
So from OneClick deployment
from our internal pipelines.

We can trigger as well
the 5G core installation
from the VPC to the network function
and as well applying the day-one config.
We tie this all together as well
with the Step Functions and Lambda

to have more granular
control of what we have
and also control the process end-to-end.

And as Zeb said before,
if we are using EKS,

we are shifting our focus from
having to upgrade platform,
having to do this heavy lifting
or being worried about the maintenance
of the infrastructure.

And again, focus on
automating our core network

but from a point of view
of the service perspective
and not the network functions.
- Maybe for you, Zeb, I feel like,

many don't always appreciate
the rapid pace of innovation

that our customers can
have in using solutions
like EKS, S3, EVS, all the solutions
and services you just mentioned

to architect these highly
complex geo-distributed
cloud native solutions.
What's one thing that you wish people knew

about some of the ways
that we've been able

to make our customers'
lives easier in deploying
but also managing these solutions?
- Yeah, that's a great question.
So if I take a step back,
in previous G, 4G, 3G, 2G,
my role was actually to do deployment
and upgrade of these systems.

Now that involved writing
100+ pages long documents
that involved testing the procedures,

that involved preparing
yourself to do rollback.

And we are talking about
like, in most of the cases,

national infrastructure
that not only allows you

to browse the internet but
that also serves the purpose

of emergency calling, lawful
intercept for example, right?

So if one thing that is
going to be very essential,
like Nahum said,

is not that you have the
best infrastructure available
to deploy 5G core,

for reliability of
infrastructure is very important
but it needs to be combined
with the agility to perform operations.

And to perform operations
in a manner where it's not,

it doesn't sound scary to have
much fine-granular control
of what operations you want to perform,
ability to introduce new features.
So for example, like,
and I know there have been established,

and standardized processes
in the telco industry
because I mean a lot of aspects of telco,
even automation is stipulated by standards
written by 3GPP, for example.

And we want to make sure
that we make it super simple
for customers like Swisscom

the overall experience
of not just onboarding

their network functions but
also running it at scale
in an automated fashion.
Like last week we announced,
a product called Network Builder.
And the main reason for Network Builder,

provided as a managed
service is that customers
can bring their own familiar tools

like writing the intent of what
you want to deploy in TOSCA
or bringing in packages

in which applications are
encapsulated as CAESAR,

and let us do the
undifferentiated heavy lifting

of basically generating
CloudFormation templates

and take that intent and
deploy the infrastructure.
So it becomes like part of,

like a natural part of
creating experiences
rather than focusing just on, "Well,

I have to deploy these
12 network functions
how I'm going to deploy them?"

- I'm really glad you brought
up Telco Network Builder,
new service we announced.
Great blog by Jeff Barr that was released.

Highly encourage everyone
to take a look at that.
But there's one thing I'm taking away
from what you just said.
It doesn't have to be scary.
I think that's really important.

As you build that mobile
core in a cloud native way,

the automation and all of
these managed AWS services
makes the developers' lives easier

so they don't have to
reverse engineer services,

as you mentioned, leverage
best-in-class tools
so they can focus on
value differentiating business activities.
So tell me about that building journey.
What AWS services did you use
and what were some of the benefits
and things that you may have
had to traditionally manage in the past
that now were managed for you?
- Basically, as I said before,
besides the Code Suite and the pipelines,

using EKS, for example,
simplified our deployments
on this case

for not having to manage
the coordinator's layer
and worry only about the containers.
Also we, by using ECR for example,

we can get our containers
analyzed for security.

That is also an important
point that we have.
So the security end-to-end,

having AWS services that
help us manage audit

and enforce security policies
from end-to-end is also great.

For example, control tower,
we can enforce guard rails

and enforce network
policy, security policies

and control what is really
happening in our network

what we allow end-to-end
connections and deployments.
- From a roadmap perspective, what's next?

What additional capabilities
are you looking for?
- Well, we actually are looking forward
to have an end-to-end orchestration

from all types of
workloads that we can use

on our internal platforms
and also in AWS for example.
And as well, it would be great to see
some telco-specific concerns protocols
and operations reported
and seen in AWS.
- And Zeb, is that what you're hearing
from customers more broadly?
Feedback similar to Nahum?
- No, yeah, absolutely.

So security has been very
important to our customers.

And I mean it's very
important to AWS as well.

So there is an aspect of
security of the cloud,
where we have our Nitro System,
which is a collection of like,
specifically designed cards for offloading

certain aspects of virtualization
like storage, networking

control, and a thin layer of
hypervisor and a security chip.

So basically as a system,
what it provides is like,
first of all to begin with,
the host on which the instances run
powering the 5G Core workload.

Those are separate from
the custom design cards
where virtualization functions run.

So that provides like
a physical isolation.
In addition to physical isolation,
they're also logically isolated

because there is no operator
access, for example,
between those components.

So like there is no SSH
access, the only way,

we can talk to those parts
of the Nitro component
is using like very hardened,

secure, encrypted, authorized,
authenticated set of APIs.

So the reason why I mentioned
that is that it allows us
to control the virtualization stack

with imperceptible impact
on customer's workloads.

And that's very important for
5G core network functions.

And it also improves overall
security posture of the cloud

because as a result of
the Nitro security chip
and Nitro controller,

the first code that goes
in any target system
which is a bootloader,

it actually goes through
a series of measurements

and it gets like
cryptographically verified
using hardware route of trust
before the system even comes online

with the software in which
you can run instances.

And that adds to the
trust and the confidence
that 5G Core customers look at
when they're running workloads, again,
where they'll have 911 or ally
and these type of functions running.
So that's one thing.

Which customers find very
important and they appreciate.
As far as the roadmap aspect is concerned,

so we launched, for
example, direct connect
to local zones for workloads

that require low latency like
UPF part of 5G Core last year.
We announced in last re:Invent instances

in the region that can support
up to 200 Gbps of throughput.
So let's say there are customers
who want to scale their UPF horizontally

where they're looking for
good CPU to throughput ratio

for, again, data end
sensor or UPF workloads,

they don't have to increase the
number of instances anymore.

We have introduced features
in EC2 and EKS related

to networking to improve
resiliency of core workloads.

So for example, EKS
introduced local clusters

where you can also run
master node on Outpost.

So if there is like let's say
fiber-cut type of a situation

and on-prem, it can still
sustain that type of event
because the master nodes of Kubernetes

are running as a result of
this feature on Outposts.

And I mean, again, there are
features like for example
spread placement on Outposts where, again,
it improves 5G Core workloads resiliency

because you can spread
an instance running,

or instead of instances
running 5G Core workloads,

across multiple hosts
within the same rack.

So there are, I mean we
are working with Swisscom

and other customers to
come up with capabilities

with which they can see
more and more functions
provided as managed service
or as undifferentiated heavy lifting

eliminated from their stack
and from ISV's stacks.

And that's what we'll
continue to innovate on.
- Well said, simply put.
The breadth and depth of services

we believe positions us as
the cloud provider of choice
for mobile core workloads.
And perhaps Nuham from your perspective,

moving away from just
the technology impact
and looking at the business impact,

through this architecture
or re-architecture

what business impact are
you expecting to achieve
for your end customers?

- Actually, the thing
that we value the most

about this is the freedom
that our engineers
and our teams have to try new things.

So before we wanted to
try a new technology,
new product or new service,

there was a lot of things
going behind the scenes

until this platform was
installed, prepared and approved.

Today we can just have
one engineer spinning
some EKS cluster and trying new things,
developing things without all this hassle.
And what we see as a business value
is that we can focus on innovating
and on creating new things,
improving our way of doing operations,
improving the way we do things

and trying to create value
added services for our customers

which is, at the end, the
most important thing for us,
create value for our customers.

- So maybe as we look to the
future, what's the next level

of cloud native mobile
course in the cloud?
- Well, (chuckles) one can dream.
If I envision this, a network that is,
from the point of view of operations,

fully automated from end-to-end
that can react to events,

and we can shift the focus
from reactive maintenance

and looking at alarms
are react from proactive
by leveraging big data analytics
to analyze the behavior of the network

and react to the changes
before we even see

any impact in production in
the end customers, for example.
- What's your vision, Zeb?
- No, yeah, completely agree with Nahum.
Just one point I want to add to that
is that there is another aspect

that for telco workloads
was very hard to achieve
in past Gs and customer expect
that we would actually innovate

and provide simple solution
to that problem as well,
and that's their sustainability goals.
So we have actually added another pillar
to a well architected framework
which is the sustainability pillar.
And as a solution architect,
if I don't help customer design solutions
that meet their sustainability goals,
I'm not doing my job as an SA, right?
So there are tools, for example,

customer carbon footprint tool
with which customers can see

what's their contribution
to the carbon footprint.

There are guidelines and
principles like for example,

using auto-scaling or
using lifecycle policies
for S3 to actually meet the target goals

pertaining to sustainability
even for telco workloads.

So we have actually customers
like, for example, NTT Docomo
that worked with AWS and NEC
to run 5G Core trial on Graviton2
and they observed up to 72%
of improvement in power consumption versus

like to like x86 instances
running that 5G Core workload

So sustainability I would
say is another key aspect.
- Fascinating discussion here today.
Really appreciate the technical depth
and rigor that we had in this discussion.
Appreciate you sharing your insights

and thanks again for
stopping by the AWS studio.
- Thank you.
- Thank you very much. Thanks, Nahum.
- Thank you, Zeb.
